Award.AwardTitle: Facilities Support: Amino Acid Geochronology Laboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
1234413
Kaufman

This Facility Support grant provides for four years of gradually phased out support for the The Amino Acid Geochronology Laboratory (AAGL) at Northern Arizona University. This facility has been supported by EAR/IF since 2004. The facility supports in excess of 5,000 sample analyses per year for in house and external users as the result of continued EAR/IF partial support of an experienced lab technician. Racemization of amino acids following the death of an organism is proportional to time elapsed since death and the temperature of the reaction environment. AA geochonology therefore provides a tool to date fossil remains for which the temperature history of the environment can be inferred or for paleothermometry if the age of the sample is determined independently (e.g., radiocarbon dating). Sample analysis is rapid and inexpensive and sample size requirements are minimal, allowing for dating of individual microfossils, for example. The history of AAGL includes broad use of the facility for a range of geoscience inquiries and applications including: deep-sea sediment chronology and bottomwater paleothermometry, paleontological time-averaging of fossil assemblages with applications to historical ecology and sequence stratigraphy, sea-level fluctuations, Quaternary tectonic history, glacial geology, terrestrial outcrop (fluvial, eolian, and lacustrine sediments) and lake-core chronostratigraphy, and island land-snail evolution. AAGL data will continue to be archived at a national center, the World Data Center for Paleoclimatology. The Facility will ultimately become self supporting by FY 2016 via gradually higher analytical charges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geochronology – the timing, frequency, and rate of geologic processes – is fundamental to nearly all Earth Science research. The extent to which proteins and their constituent amino acids have been affected by chemical reactions can be used to infer their relative ages. Amino acids are preserved in fossils for millions of years (over the Quaternary Period), where they undergo slow and systematic reactions. Among these reactions is the racemization of amino acids, their interconversion from one chiral form (the L - (laevo) amino acids, which are the building blocks of proteins), to a mixture of L- and D- (dextro) forms (isomers). The extent of racemization is measured by the ratio of D/L isomers and increases as a function of time and temperature, and can be used for geochronlogy. Amino acid geochronology is best suited as a relative-dating tool, or as a calibrated-dating method in conjunction with other dating techniques. It is applicable to a wide range of fossils types (especially those with carbonate skeletons: mollusks, ostracodes, foraminifera, echinoderms egg shells, and teeth), stratigraphic problems (correlations, reworking, unconformities), depositional environments (marine, lacustrine, fluvial), and time scales (decades to millions of years). It is particularly useful for fossiliferous deposits beyond the range of radiocarbon dating (older than about 40,000 years), for which few alternative geochronological tools are available

The Amino Acid Geochronology Laboratory (AAGL) at Northern Arizona University was established as an NSF-EAR-IF Multi-User Facility in 2004. This last award period extended from September 1, 2012 to August 31, 2016. During this time, the AAGL transitioned from an NSF-supported, Multi-User Facility to a cost-recovery accounting model. Despite the phase-out of NSF support during the award period, the AAGL analyzed 8135 specimens (more than the goal of 6000 analyses that was specified in the original proposal), and reported results to 42 collaborating scientists. Their research topics involved in a broad range of geoscience disciplines including: historical ecology, archeology, paleontology, paleoceanography, tectonic geomorphology, glacial geology, and many others.

The majority of the analyses were in support of studies focused on historical ecology. For this application, amino acid geochronology is used to determine the age of individual fragments of marine shells that comprise fossil death assemblages — large collections of mixed ages. These assemblages attest to the species composition of communities in the past. They are used to determine the extent of anthropogenic changes and as long-term baselines. Other studies are aimed at quantifying the temporal resolution of paleoenviron­mental information that ultimately can be derived from a fossil assemblage, which is determined by its range of ages (time-averaging).

A primary indicator of the scientific impact of the AAGL is the number of articles that were published in international peer-reviewed journals that contain data generated by the lab. During the four-year funding period, results from the AAGL were published in at least 26 peer-reviewed articles, two book chapters and 17 abstracts for professional meetings (and two other articles are now in review). This amounts to about 24% of all articles published on amino acid geochronology internationally during this period (based on an analysis of the Web of Science bibliographic database; Fig. 1). Since the AAGL was established as an NSF Multi-User Facility, the number of publications featuring amino acid geochronology has grown, reversing the declining publication rate of the previous ten years, and overcoming the closure of North American laboratories specializing in the technique.

During the four-year funding period, this award supported a full-time laboratory manager (Whitacre), hosted two researchers (Albano, Univ. Wien, Austria; Briner, Univ. Buffalo), provided them travel support, and trained them in AAR analytical procedures. The AAGL employed one graduate student (Belanger) and three undergraduate students (Hermosisima, Johnson, Soderberg). The AAGL facilitated the archival of amino acid geochronology data in the on-line database that it helped develop through the World Data Center for Paleoclimatology.
